conclusion: All knowledge is limited to phenomena; we cannot know the nature of reality in itself (the "Unknowable")
There exists an "Unknowable" ultimate reality underlying all phenomena
The force behind cosmic evolution is unknown and unknowable
Human understanding is capable only of "relative" knowledge, not absolute knowledge
Space, time, force, motion, and substance cannot be completely known in their ultimate nature
Science and religion can be reconciled through shared acknowledgment of the Unknowable
Ultimate scientific and religious ideas cannot be fully rationally established
The Unknowable represents the final evolutionary stage of religion—the elimination of anthropomorphic vestiges
Worship of the Unknowable can serve as a positive basis for religious sentiment
Knowledge is subject to change because that which is known is in a process of evolution
Empirical demonstration is required for knowledge about phenomena
Starting from either religion or science, we are driven to accept inconceivable notions
Evolution is a universal law applying to all phenomena—physical, biological, psychological, and social
Evolution proceeds from simple, undifferentiated homogeneity to complex, differentiated heterogeneity
Evolution involves increasing integration of differentiated parts
Evolution is "an integration of matter and concomitant dissipation of motion"
All natural laws can be reduced to one fundamental law: the law of evolution
Evolution has a direction and endpoint—the attainment of a final state of equilibrium
The law of evolution applies equally to stars, galaxies, organisms, minds, and societies
Progress is not accidental but necessary
Evolution applies to the cosmos as a universal process
Dissolution (the reverse of evolution) is also a universal process that undoes evolved forms
The persistence of force is a fundamental law of matter from which evolutionary processes follow
Lamarckian inheritance of acquired characteristics is a primary mechanism of evolution
Organs develop or diminish through use or disuse
Acquired characteristics can be transmitted to future generations
Natural selection is a secondary mechanism of evolution, less important than use-inheritance
Spencer coined the phrase "survival of the fittest" (before Darwin adopted it)
Evolution explains "higher" developments, especially social development of humanity
Biological organisms evolve from simple to complex forms
Physiological "units" are responsible for transmission of characteristics to offspring
The primary evolutionary mechanism is "direct equilibration" (use-inheritance)
"Indirect equilibration" (natural selection) plays a supporting role in evolution
Species transformation results primarily from inherited functional modifications
Evolution produces greater specialization and individuation in organisms
The human mind is subject to natural laws discoverable within general biology
Psychology should be approached from a developmental and evolutionary perspective
Mental evolution occurs at individual, species, and racial levels
Repeated associations of ideas become embodied in specific strands of brain tissue
Mental associations can be inherited through Lamarckian use-inheritance
Feelings are a class of mental elements distinct from sensations
Nervous "shocks" (bursts of nervous activity) are the basic units of consciousness
Relations between feelings are felt but can only exist between two feelings
The mind develops through correspondence between internal and external relations
Associationist psychology and phrenology are both partial truths that can be reconciled
Mental faculties evolved to promote survival and adaptation
Human psychology represents the culmination of evolutionary development
Consciousness exists in each individual member of society, not in society as a whole
Intelligence involves adjustment of internal relations to external relations
Happiness is the ultimate end to be contemplated (utilitarian standard)
Happiness should not be the proximate end—moral conduct should follow from principles
The greatest happiness of the greatest number is the ultimate standard of value
Morality is a science that can deduce laws of conduct from laws of life
There exists an innate "moral sense" by which humans arrive at moral intuitions
Good and bad are defined by pleasurable or painful consequences
Moral intuitions become biologically inheritable through evolution
Pleasure-producing activities generate inheritable associations between actions and approval
Utilitarianism gradually becomes intuitive through evolutionary development
"Absolute Ethics" provides a scientifically grounded moral system
"Relative Ethics" accounts for our present moral imperfections
Altruism and compassion beyond family are recently evolved sentiments in humans
Sympathy is the single most important component of justice
Moral rights are indefeasible (unlike Mill's view that they are defeasible)
Rational egoists pursuing self-interest will not fundamentally conflict with one another
Caring for those unrelated to oneself encourages laziness and works against evolution
Moral progress occurs as "empirical utilitarianism" gives way to "rational utilitarianism"
The culmination of evolution will be the maximization of utility
In the perfect society, individuals will derive pleasure from exercising altruism
Conduct restrained within equal freedom promotes harmonious cooperation
"Law of Equal Freedom": Every person has freedom to do all they will, provided they don't infringe equal freedom of others
Liberty means the absence of coercion
The state is not an "essential" institution and will decay over time
Voluntary market organization will replace coercive aspects of the state
Individuals have a "right to ignore the state" (early view, later abandoned)
Government's only legitimate function is policing and protection of individual rights
Education, religion, economy, and care for the sick should not be undertaken by the state
Law and public authority exist for administration of justice (equated with freedom and rights protection)
Parliamentary government exhibits a virtual "divine right" claiming unbounded power
Political association should model a "joint stock company" requiring explicit shareholder consent
Parliaments imposing conceptions of the good are no different from tyrannies
Government action requires individual consent
Laissez-faire is the appropriate economic policy
Government intervention causes more problems than it solves
New regulations are constantly needed to repair damage from prior interventions
Socialism is tantamount to slavery in limiting human freedom
Imperialism and colonial expansion subvert evolutionary progress
Militarism and conscription are unjust impositions
Private charity should replace government welfare programs
Voluntary association and informal care are preferred to government bureaucracy
19th-century "New Liberalism" was actually a "New Toryism"—enemy of liberty
The coming "slavery" is the drift toward collectivism and state control
Basic rights exist in virtue of human constitution
Rights include life, liberty, property, and free speech
Rights to equal freedom for women (early view)
Universal suffrage as a political right (early view, later abandoned)
Private land ownership is incompatible with equal freedom (early view, later abandoned)
Every citizen has a right to use of the earth (early view)
"Political rights" are interim devices for moral imperfection, not authentic moral rights
Moral rights ("rights properly so-called") are specifications of equal freedom
Rights are natural in that they valorize customs arising to ameliorate social friction
Society is analogous to a biological organism ("social organism")
Society has a regulative system (government) analogous to the nervous system
Society has a sustaining system (industry) analogous to alimentation
Society has a distribution system (roads, telegraphs) analogous to veins and arteries
Society exists for benefit of its members, not members for society's benefit (key difference from biological organism)
Social evolution proceeds from undifferentiated hordes to complex civilizations
Division of labor is a key mechanism of social progress
There are two types of society: militant and industrial
Militant society is structured around hierarchy, obedience, and force
Industrial society is based on voluntary, contractual social obligations
Evolution transforms militant societies into industrial societies
Simple societies are nomadic with low differentiation and specialization
Compound societies result from merger of simple societies
Social institutions differentiate like organs in a developing embryo
"Social statics" studies conditions of social order
"Social dynamics" studies human progress and evolution
Religion originated in worship of ghosts or ancestors
Religious evolution progresses from primitive worship to agnostic scientific consciousness
Professional institutions illustrate social evolution conforming to universal evolutionary law
Free market competition improves well-being of society
Private enterprise and voluntary exchange should replace state direction
The fittest business enterprises survive through competition
Economic regulation harms personal freedom and prosperity
Wage-labor should ideally be replaced by free worker cooperatives (early view)
Trade unions are a legitimate bulwark against exploitation by bosses
Commerce and trade generate independent sources of freedom separate from state
Science is the knowledge of most worth
The study of science provides the most valuable knowledge
Traditional classical curriculum (humanities) should be criticized
Self-development is essential to education
Observation and problem-solving are key educational methods
Physical exercise and free play are important
Discipline should derive from natural consequences, not punishments imposed by teachers
Sympathetic attention from instructors is important
Education should teach everyone how to live completely
Science underlies sculpture, painting, music, and poetry
Science and poetry are not opposed—science is itself poetic
Opposition to national education under central government
Private schools competing for students would lead to better education
Education should teach practical skills benefiting society
Religion and religious doctrine are appropriate objects of empirical investigation
General position on religion is agnostic—we cannot know if God exists
Theism cannot be adopted because there is no means to acquire knowledge of the divine
We cannot know that fundamental religious beliefs are false either
Attributing human personality to God degrades God (anti-anthropomorphism)
Religion will not disappear but will evolve
Religious sentiment—humility and wonder before incomprehensible reality—will persist
Traditional theology with promises of reward and threats of damnation will continue to decline
The "Infinite and Eternal Energy from which all things proceed" is the refined religious object
Ecclesiastical institutions may vanish but religious sentiment will remain
